ideology.title: Ho Chi Minh‚Äôs Thought on National Independence

nationalIndependence.title: Independence and freedom are the sacred, inviolable rights of all peoples
nationalIndependence.desc: Vietnam‚Äôs long history of nation-building and defense is inseparable from the tradition of patriotism and resistance against foreign aggression. It expresses our people‚Äôs profound aspiration for national independence and the freedom of the people ‚Äî a sacred, imperishable value embodied by Ho Chi Minh. He said: ‚ÄòWhat I desire most in life is that my compatriots have freedom and my Fatherland independence.‚Äô

nationalIndependence.title: National independence must be tied to the people‚Äôs freedom, subsistence, and happiness
nationalIndependence.desc: According to Ho Chi Minh, national independence must go hand in hand with the people‚Äôs freedom. He highly valued Sun Yat-sen‚Äôs ‚ÄòThree Principles of the People‚Äô on independence and freedom: national independence, people‚Äôs rights (freedom), and people‚Äôs livelihood (well-being). Citing the French Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen (1791) ‚Äî ‚ÄòAll men are born free and equal in rights, and must always remain free and equal in rights‚Äô ‚Äî Ho Chi Minh affirmed that the Vietnamese nation must also be free and equal in rights. ‚ÄòThat is a truth no one can deny.‚Äô

nationalIndependence.title: Independence must be genuine, complete, and thorough
nationalIndependence.desc: Independence and freedom are not only goals but also conditions to bring happiness to the people.

nationalIndependence.title: Independence goes hand in hand with national unity and territorial integrity
nationalIndependence.desc: Independence and freedom are not only goals but also conditions to bring happiness to the people.

nationalRevolution.title: To triumph, the national liberation revolution must follow the path of the proletarian revolution
nationalRevolution.desc: Since the French invasion and colonial rule, the Vietnamese nation faced the existential task of liberating itself from imperialist domination. Numerous patriotic movements arose but failed; their failure revealed a crisis and deadlock regarding revolutionary leadership and line. Surpassing the horizons of his predecessors, Ho Chi Minh set out to seek a path to national salvation in the West.

nationalRevolution.title: In Vietnam‚Äôs conditions, the national liberation revolution must be led by the Communist Party
nationalRevolution.desc: Marxism‚ÄìLeninism stresses the decisive role of the Communist Party: it is the subjective factor enabling the working class to fulfill its historic mission. The working class must have its political party; that party must persuade, enlighten, organize, train, and lead the masses into struggle. Ho Chi Minh absorbed Marxist‚ÄìLeninist theory and attached great importance to founding the Communist Party, affirming its pivotal role in the national liberation revolution along the proletarian path.

nationalRevolution.title: Rely on great national unity, with the worker‚Äìpeasant alliance as the foundation
nationalRevolution.desc: Classical Marxist‚ÄìLeninist theory affirms: revolution is the cause of the masses; the people are the creators of history. V. I. Lenin wrote: ‚ÄòWithout the sympathy and support of the vast majority of the working people for its vanguard ‚Äî the proletariat ‚Äî the proletarian revolution cannot be carried out.‚Äô

nationalRevolution.title: Be proactive and creative; colonial revolutions can win before the proletarian revolution in the metropole
nationalRevolution.desc: At times, the Communist International underestimated the colonial revolution, viewing it as dependent on the proletarian revolution in the metropole. The Sixth Comintern Congress (1928) adopted theses on revolutionary movements in colonies and semi-colonies stating that complete liberation would only be possible after the proletariat triumphed in advanced capitalist countries. This view had adverse effects, diminishing the initiative and creativity of colonial peoples in their struggle for independence.

nationalRevolution.title: Carry out the national liberation revolution by the method of revolutionary violence
nationalRevolution.desc: In Capital (Vol. I, 1867), Karl Marx wrote: ‚ÄòForce is the midwife of every old society pregnant with a new one.‚Äô In 1878, in Anti-D√ºhring, Friedrich Engels reiterated: ‚ÄòForce also plays another role in history ‚Äî a revolutionary role; in Marx‚Äôs words, it is the midwife of every old society pregnant with a new one; force is the instrument whereby social movement forces its way and shatters obsolete forms.‚Äô
